Articles.Content:
I am going to start making mod packs for KSP. If you play Minecraft, you would know that mod packs make it easier to share crafts/maps because you would just have to download the pack, and the map/craft and there you go, you have installed the map/craft and required mods in two simple steps.

The first mod pack I am going to create is one geared for creative building and a little realism. Mods:

*Parts Mods

Aies Aerospace

B9 Aerospace

Kw Rocketry

Nova(Slug)Punch

Mk2 Cockpit Internals

6S Service

RLA Stockalike mods

Procedural Parts

Procedural Fairings

Space Shuttle Engines

Fustek

KSPX

Infernal Robotics

*Feature Mods

RCS Build Aid

Kerbal Engineer

MechJeb

Active Memory Reduction Mod

*Alteration mods:

FAR

Deadly Reentry

TAC Life Suport

More Mods To Be Listed! I am still looking at what I want.

If you own one of these mods, please let me know if it is okay to use it in my pack.

Make sure you check and adhere to the licenses of those mods very carefully to ensure you can redistribute. KSPX, for one, cannot be redistributed without express permission. AIES is also quite questionable, you should definitely PM the author. Space Shuttle Engines is "no derivatives", so make sure that's redistributed as-is (might even apply to distributing it as the original zip package, best to PM dtobi).

The FusTek licence technically and legally permits you to redistribute it as long as you properly attribute its author (i.e. myself).

However, I wouldn't recommended including it in the pack, as it is still under heavy development and there are constant changes/tweaks to features parts, and so whatever version you have currently included will be out of date quite quickly - effectively turning the whole idea of mod packs an exercise in futility.

While FAR (being licensed under GPL v3) does allow you to redistribute it, I'd prefer you not do so. In any case, since I won't know what version you're packing if you do decide to go ahead without my explicit blessing, I won't provide any support to your users; you will have to be responsible for providing support for FAR for users of your pack. I would expect that any other plugin authors would have a similar attitude, so you're looking at supporting several plugins that you have no idea what the code does or how it functions. If you do decide to go ahead with this, (and understand that I'm not pleased with any of these ideas) you are responsible for cleaning up any messes you create and dealing with all the user woes that come from it; it's not going to be any of our problems, since we don't know what you've changed in the process of putting that together, and frankly, we shouldn't have to clean up someone else's mess.

Also having AIES, KW, B9, NovaPunch and KSPX together, without even counting all of the parts from the other mods, is a bad idea. Even with ATM its a lot of memory, and the VAB menus will just be crammed full.

There is very little positive gain from "Packs" and a lot of negative consquences. You, as the pack maintainer, need to update it OFTEN or you just creative version mismatches and support nightmares. If you give up after a month then you've wasted your time and created work for others.

KSP isn't minecraft - it doesn't need packs. I urge you to reconsider.

I was also going to use the reduced textures to help with the data management. And as for the VAB being crammed, there are parts organizers that will help.

Your right, there isn't too many mods for KSP, so kinda no need to put packs together.

EDIT One reason that I was doing this is that I have a lot of time because its summer break, and i don't have a lot to do other than play video games and read (both get really boring eventually), and this was something to do. Second, when I first downloaded mods, I was very confused on how to do it, and I thought this was just an easy way to let people mass download mods in one quick download and extraction.

If i do do make a mod pack, I should probably wait till some of the fallowing.

*KSP is in the 1.0 phase

*More mods (if any) are in 1.0

*I know how to code (to be able to fix problems with code)

*There are actually more mods (and they become harder to track)

I see everyone's point, it would be a lot of work. But if there is a lot more mods in the future there might be more point into making mod packs. For now, its just easier to have a list like somnambulist said.
